key_points: Gov. Gavin Newsom proposes expanding the Golden State Stimulus to include $600 checks for Californians earning up to $75,000.
The proposal includes paying down back rent for tenants and assisting millions in catching up on utility bills due to the COVID-19 impact.
California reports a $75.7 billion surplus, allowing Newsom to propose the largest state tax rebate in U.S. history.
Newsom's plan is part of a $100 billion California comeback initiative, leveraging $26 billion in federal relief funds.
The expanded Golden State Stimulus would provide $11.9 billion for $600 payments, $5.2 billion for rent relief, $2 billion for utility bills, and $1 billion in college grants.
The proposal aims to address the economic disparity caused by the pandemic, especially among low-wage workers and people of color.
Republican challengers criticize the plan as politically motivated due to the impending recall election.
78% of California tax filers would receive a stimulus payment under Newsom's plan.
Advocates push for greater relief for undocumented immigrants, who have been largely excluded from federal relief.
The state's eviction moratorium is set to expire on June 30, making the rent relief proposal urgent.
spokespersons: Senator Nancy Skinner (Oakland Democrat, Senate budget committee lead)
Phil Ting (San Francisco Democrat, Assembly counterpart)
